SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the reader

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If you cannot fill in all the blanks, there is still sufficient space on this form to describe particular events or experiences which may help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate answers or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All Questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed Questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, SASK.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A record of experiences relating to the pioneer life in Saskatchewan.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about having blank spaces. If U.S. citizens or persons of other nationalities have lived in Saskatchewan, it is desirable to give detailed answers to such questions. If you have any information that might help to answer the questions, please give it.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and any person who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. It may be sent (already answered) and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?  
   Not much. At first they thought I wouldn't stay very long.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?  
   Party of three.

13. What means of transportation did you use?  
   By train to Saskatchewan.

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences etc.).  
   We started off well for each other, but then only had two days of good weather in seven days. We had to work hard, but we also had two days of good weather. We met some friendly Indians who helped us along. We also met some unfriendly Indians who tried to steal our supplies. We had to build ourselves a little house, but it was fairly cheap and easy. We used two logs of wood, one for the floor and one for the walls. We came across a field that was very difficult to get through.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?  
   Saskatoon.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?  
   Saskatoon.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.  
   None.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?  
   Worked in town for several years.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Not much. Let they be. I should not say any more.

12. Did you travel by train or by horse? (Specify mode of travel)

By train.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train to Edmonton. Then walked back to the beach.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

We could all get along well. Only Indian trading took a lot of food in every station. We knew we would need two wagons, so we bought two wagons out of the old lumber yard. They had good wagons, but they were very heavy. We had to build ourselves a lot of them. We also had some cows and a few sheep. We also had a few goats.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Edmonton.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Meadow Lake district No. 8-1943

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

None.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Worked as hand for several years.
